abstract.text: A task scheduler suitable for low priority operations that can run in the background.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Use an
object to schedule an arbitrary maintenance or background task. It’s similar to an
object, in that it lets you schedule a repeating or non-repeating task. However,
gives the system flexibility to determine the most efficient time to execute based on energy usage, thermal conditions, and CPU use.
For example, use an
object to schedule:
Automatic saves
Backups
Data maintenance
Periodic content fetches
Installation of updates
Activities occurring in intervals of 10 minutes or more
Any other deferrable task
For information about performing non-deferrable tasks efficiently, see
in
The
class interfaces with the XPC Activity API. However, your app doesn’t need to be an XPC service in order to use
To initialize a scheduler, call
for
, and pass it a unique identifier string in reverse DNS notation (
and zero-length strings are not allowed) that remains constant across launches of your application. See

abstract.text: Creating a scheduler

inlineContent.text: The system uses this unique identifier to track the number of times the activity has run and to improve the heuristics for deciding when to run it again in the future.
Configure the scheduler with any of the following scheduling properties:
—If set to
, the activity is rescheduled at the specified interval after finishing.
—For repeating schedulers, the average interval between invocations of the activity. For nonrepeating schedulers,
is the suggested interval of time between scheduling the activity and the invocation of the activity.

—The amount of time before or after the nominal fire date when the activity should be invoked. The nominal fire date is calculated by using the interval combined with the previous fire date or the time when the activity is started. These two properties create a window in time, during which the activity may be scheduled. The system will more aggressively schedule the activity as it nears the end of the grace period after the nominal fire date. The default value is half the interval.
—The default value is

. If you upgrade the quality of service above this level, the system schedules the activity more aggressively. The default value is the recommended value for most activities. For information on quality of service, see
in
, and
demonstrate different scheduling scenarios.

abstract.text: Scheduling an activity to fire in the next 10 minutes
Scheduling an activity to fire between 15 and 45 minutes from now
Scheduling an activity to fire once each hour

inlineContent.text: When you’re ready to schedule the activity, call
and provide a block of code to execute when the scheduler runs, as shown in
. The block will be called on a serial background queue appropriate for the level of quality of service specified. The system automatically uses the
method (of
) while invoking the block, choosing appropriate options based on the specified quality of service.
When your block is called, it’s passed a completion handler as an argument. Configure the block to invoke this handler, passing it a result of type
to indicate whether the activity finished (
) or should be deferred (

) and rescheduled for a later time. Failure to invoke the completion handler results in the activity not being rescheduled. For work that will be deferred and rescheduled, the block may optionally adjust scheduler properties, such as
or
, before calling the completion handler.

abstract.text: Scheduling background activity

inlineContent.text: It’s conceivable that while a lengthy activity is running, conditions may change, resulting in the activity now requiring deferral. For example, perhaps the user has unplugged the Mac and it’s now running on battery power. Your activity can call
to determine whether this has occurred. A value of
indicates that the block should finish what it’s currently doing and invoke its completion handler with a value of
. See

code: // Wrap up processing and prepare to defer activity

abstract.text: Detecting deferred background activity

inlineContent.text: Call
to stop scheduling an activity, as shown in

abstract.text: Stopping background activity

inlineContent.text: When an activity is stopped, a block that’s currently executing will still finish executing.

abstract.text: A task scheduler suitable for low priority operations that can run in the background.
Creating a scheduler
Scheduling an activity to fire in the next 10 minutes
Scheduling an activity to fire between 15 and 45 minutes from now
Scheduling an activity to fire once each hour
Scheduling background activity
Detecting deferred background activity
Stopping background activity
Initializes a background activity scheduler object with a specified unique identifier.
A value of type
, which specifies a range of time during which the background activity may occur.
An integer providing a suggested interval between scheduling and invoking the activity.
Prevents the background activity from being scheduled again.
A Boolean value indicating whether the activity should be rescheduled after it completes.
A Boolean value indicating whether your app should stop performing background activity and resume at a more optimal time.
A unique reverse DNS notation string, such as
, that identifies the activity.
A value of type
, which controls how aggressively the system schedules the activity.
Begins scheduling the background activity.
These constants indicate whether background activity has been completed successfully or whether additional processing should be deferred until a more optimal time.
A collection of information about the current process.
Constants that indicate the nature and importance of work to the system.
